snippet: Lawyers for the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed after refusing to issue marriage licenses to gay couples said they have begun the process of appealing the judge’s ruling on the grounds that her right to due process was violated.
abstract: Rowan County, Ky, clerk Kim Davis, who was imprisoned for refusing to sign same-sex marriage licenses, is appealing decision, claiming violation of due process; her stand, lauded by religious conservatives, is emerging as issue for Republican presidential candidates.

byline.original: By LIAM STACK and ASHLEY SOUTHALL

lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed after refusing to issue marriage licenses to gay couples said they have begun the process of appealing the judge’s ruling on the grounds that her right to due process was violated.

headline.main: Jailed Kentucky Clerk Starts Federal Appeal
headline.print_headline: Jailed Kentucky Clerk Starts Federal Appeal

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
